moves.1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 d6: The Old Steinitz Defense, which *usually* leads to a cramped position in which Black must fight for a draw. Key word: usually. NOT always.
moves.6. Nc3 Nf6 7. O-O Be7: With Alekhine having secured his King, Capablanca prepares to do the same.
moves.8. Nf5 Bxf5 9. exf5 O-O: Hastily getting his King to safety, away from the now fully open K file.
moves.10. Re1 Nd7 11. Nd5 Bf6: Alekhine has a large spatial advantage. Capablanca, however, has no exploitable weaknesses.
moves.12. c3 Nb6 13. Nxf6+ Qxf6: Alekhine has two B's vs. two Knights, but the exchanges have helped Capablaca free his position.
moves.14. Bxc6 bxc6 15. Qf3 Rfe8: Contesting the open file now that his Rooks are connected.
moves.16. Be3 c5 17. Re2 Re5: Threatening to take over the file with ...R/1-K1, doubling Rooks.
moves.18. Rae1 Rae8 19. Qb7 Qxf5: Capa's Q is now in a dominating central position. He can now triple major pieces on the K-file, forming a powerful battery.
moves.20. Qxc7 Qe6 21. Qxa7 Nd5: Bringing the Knight into the game. White's Q has been diverted by Pawns into a position where it is out of play.
moves.22. Kf1 Nf4 23. Rd2 Nxg2: A wonderful sacrifce to break open the King's defenses.
moves.24. Kxg2 Qg4+ 25. Kf1 Qh3+: Trying to corral the White King.
moves.26. Ke2 Re5xe3+: Another sacrifice, to remove yet another defender.
moves.27. fxe3 Qxe3+: Now Capa will win back a Rook.
moves.29. Kc2 Qe4+: Leaving Capablanca with both a material and positional advantage.
moves.30. Kb3 Qc6 31. a4 d5: Preventing the K from escaping into the center of the board.
moves.34. Ka2 h6: To avoid any last-minute back-rank mate possiblities for Alekhine.
moves.35. a6 Qb3+: Alekhine resigns. The finish would be 36 K-R1 (or K-N1) R-K1, and mate follows on the back rank, unless Alekhine gives up his Rook with 37 R-Q1 QxR ch 38 K-R2, which would of course leave him hopelessly behind in material.

players: Aleksandr Alekhine  vs. Jose R. Capablanca
opening: Ruy Lopez (C62), old Steinitz defence, Nimzovich attack
